thread.title: Jealous to unveil Baltimore police reform plan. First step: Fire bad cops
thread.title_full: Jealous to unveil Baltimore police reform plan. First step: Fire bad cops

author: Luke Broadwater
title: Jealous to unveil Baltimore police reform plan. First step: Fire bad cops
text:
Luke Broadwater Contact Reporter The Baltimore Sun 
Former NAACP President Ben Jealous and the Center for American Progress on Friday plan to release a six-point plan to improve policing in Baltimore that includes the firing of "corrupt" officers and the removal of gag orders from police misconduct settlements. 
The plan, which was created with input from 25 community, faith and civil rights organizations in Baltimore called The Campaign for Justice, Safety, and Jobs, also calls for the city to distribute body cameras to all police officers within one year, while ensuring the video is available to the public, and the training of every officer in "de-escalation techniques." 
"When there have been uprisings like we had last April in response to grievous acts of police brutality, the city remains in a vulnerable place until the verdicts in the officers' case are handled down," said Jealous, a senior fellow at the Center for American Progress, who wrote the 16-page report. "That's why it's so important to be courageous in this moment." 
Additionally, the report recommends the department improve community policing and publish all departmental policies online. 
Jealous and the organizations plan a news conference Friday to announce the recommendations. Jealous said he began working on the plan after the death of Freddie Gray in April. 
Gray suffered a severe spinal cord injury while in police custody. His death sparked weeks of protests, and his funeral on April 27 was followed by a several hours of rioting, looting and arson. 
Jealous' report focuses on reforming police misconduct. There are no recommendations about lowering crime. 
In an interview, he said crime would go down once trust is established between the police and community members. 
"You're not going to get greater cooperation, which is necessary to solve homicides, until they feel that they can trust you," he said. "Increasing trust lowers crime rates." 
The report comes after interim police commissioner Kevin Davis received a vote of approval from a City Council committee amid protests. Davis next week will go before the full City Council to determine whether he will become Baltimore's 38th police chief. 
Jealous said it is still "too early" to judge Davis' performance. 
"I'm not going to second-guess the council," Jealous said. "Like everybody in the city, I'm hopeful he's going to lead us in the right direction." 
The police department did not immediately respond to a request for comment, but has begun work on some of the same goals. 
For instance, this month, the city plans to begin a pilot program to equip a total of 155 officers with body cameras.
